title-group.article-title: Examining the Factor Structure and Discriminant Validity of the 12-Item General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12) Among Spanish Postpartum Women

article-meta.aff: 2Sant Joan de Déu—Mental Health Services, Barcelona, Spain
4Institut d’Investigacions Biomèdiques August Pi i Sunyer (IDIBAPS), Barcelona, Spain
5Hospital Clínic Universitari de Barcelona, Barcelona, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Jaume Aguado, Research and Development Unit, Sant Joan de Déu—Mental Health Services, Doctor Antoni Pujadas 42, Sant Boi de Llobregat, 08830, Barcelona, Spain Email: jaguado@pssjd.org

abstract.p: In this study, the authors tested alternative factor models of the 12-item General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12) in a sample of Spanish postpartum women, using confirmatory factor analysis. The authors report the results of modeling three different methods for scoring the GHQ-12 using estimation methods recommended for categorical and binary data. A discriminant function analysis was also performed to test the utility of a multiple factor model. A two-phase cross-sectional study was designed: (a) 1,453 women visiting at 6 weeks postpartum completed the GHQ-12 and the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale questionnaire and (b) based on the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale outcomes, participants were stratified and randomly selected within each stratum for clinical evaluation. Using the Likert-type scoring approach, Hankins’s one-factor model with “method effects” obtained the best fit. In addition, Graetz’s three-factor model provided little discrimination between diagnostic groups, the factors being highly correlated. These results support the presence of only one latent factor in the GHQ-12.

body.p: The General Health Questionnaire (GHQ; Goldberg, 1972, 1978) is a well-established measure of psychological morbidity. It was originally designed to detect psychiatric morbidity among general medical outpatients and in the community. Several forms are available, which are adaptations of the original 60-item questionnaire. Three shorter versions have 30, 28, and 12 items each.

The original method of scoring the GHQ was a binary method; symptomatic responses to each item are scored “1” and summed over the items. This has been characterized as the (0-0-1-1) method, as adjacent response categories are collapsed. For the GHQ-12, this method results in a score ranging from 0 to 12. Goodchild and Duncan-Jones (1985) suggested a modification of the original scoring method where negatively phrased items were scored (0-1-1-1) and positively phrased items were scored as in the original. The GHQ can also be scored using a 4-point Likert-type scale where scores of 0 to 3 are assigned to each item response and then summed across items, giving a total score ranging from 0 to 36 (0-1-2-3 method). Some authors have suggested that the Likert-type scoring method would be the most appropriate for statistical purposes (Winefield, Goldney, Winefield, & Tiggemann, 1989).

Several authors have examined the factor structure of the GHQ-12, but the findings have been diverse and contradictory. For instance, Banks et al. (1980), Banks and Jackson (1982), Winefield et al. (1989), and Hankins (2008a, 2008b) found that it is best understood as a unidimensional scale, whereas others have identified two factors (Gureje & Obikoya, 1990; Politi, Piccinelli, & Wilkinson, 1994; Schmitz, Kruse, & Tress, 1999) or three factors (Campbell & Knowles, 2007; Cheung, 2002; French & Tait, 2004; Gao et al., 2004; Graetz, 1991; Ip & Martin, 2006; Mäkikangas et al., 2006; A. J. Martin, 1999; C. R. Martin & Newell, 2005; Penninkilampi-Kerola, Miettunen, & Ebeling, 2006). This heterogeneity complicates the use of the GHQ-12 as an instrument, and this has led to some authors reporting on the replicability of the factor structures proposed (Campbell, Walker, & Farrell, 2003; French & Tait, 2004; Mäkikangas et al., 2006). In general, all studies have identified common factors of depressed mood and stress. The three-factor models have also found a factor that has been conceived as social support (Daradkeh, Ghubash, & El Rufaie, 2001; Farrell, 1998; Graetz, 1991; A. J. Martin, 1999; Worsley & Gribbin, 1977).

Recently, Hankins (2008a) pointed out that previous studies had not taken into account a possible response bias on the negatively phrased items. Thus, he conducted a study with a large sample and observed that the variances on the six negative items (2, 5, 6, 9, 10, and 11) were uniformly greater than those on the six positive items. This response bias was caused by the ambiguous response options for items indicating the absence of negative mood states. Finally, he confirmed that a unidimensional model with correlated error terms on the negative-phrased items provided a substantially better fit than the unidimensional model without correlated errors, a two-factor model previously obtained with an exploratory factor analysis, or the Graetz (1991) model of three factors.

Most confirmatory factor analyses (CFAs) of the GHQ-12 reported to date have used estimation methods that assume that the variables are normally distributed or at least continuous (Campbell et al., 2003; Gao et al., 2004; Hankins, 2008a, 2008b; Kalliath, O’Driscoll, & Brough, 2004; C. R. Martin & Newell, 2005; Penninkilampi-Kerola et al., 2006; Shevlin & Adamson, 2005). This fact has generally been ignored and it was not until the past few years that some studies mentioned it and stated that a different estimator should be used (Campbell & Knowles, 2007; French & Tait, 2004; Ip & Martin, 2006; Mäkikangas et al., 2006). It is well known from both statistical theory and prior simulation studies that considering ordinal variables as if they were continuous and thus using maximum likelihood methods, based on the sample product–moment correlation or covariance matrix of the observed ordinal variables, does not perform well especially when the number of categories is small (e.g., five or fewer). In particular, the chi-square model fit statistic is inflated (Babakus, Ferguson, & Jöreskog, 1987; Green, Akey, Fleming, Hershberger, & Marquis, 1997; Hutchinson & Olmos, 1998; Muthén & Kaplan, 1992), parameters are underestimated (Babakus et al., 1987; Muthén & Kaplan, 1992), and standard error estimates tend to be downwardly biased (Muthén, 1984; Muthén & Kaplan, 1992). Alternative estimation methods have been available for a while and have been recommended in the presence of ordinal data (Flora & Curran, 2004; Jöreskog, 1990; Muthén, 1984; Wang & Cunningham, 2005).

The present study was thus conducted with the main objective of studying the structure of the GHQ-12, in a sample of postpartum women, using statistical methods that are more suitable for categorical and binary data to be able to assess the following research questions:

list-item.p: Is the GHQ-12 best understood as a unitary measure of psychiatric morbidity when taking method effects into account?
Is the structure of the GHQ-12 consistent across the three scoring methods?
Is there an advantage to using a multidimensional approach to scoring in terms of the discrimination among postpartum women suffering from mood, anxiety, or nonmental disorders?

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: Potential subjects included all Spanish women scheduled for a routine postnatal checkup (6 weeks after delivery) at the Obstetrics and Gynecology Unit of an acute-care teaching hospital in Barcelona (Spain) over a 1-year period. Women were excluded from the study if they (a) did not speak Spanish, (b) had a stillbirth, (c) did not read or write, or (5) did not provide informed consent.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The data presented in this study were gathered as part of a larger project studying psychiatric morbidity, maternity, and employment that was conducted between January 2001 and January 2002. The research protocol was approved by the institutional review board, and all participants provided written informed consent. The sampling procedures have previously been described (Navarro et al., 2007). In brief, a two-phase cross-sectional study was designed. In the first phase, 1,453 women visiting at 6 weeks postpartum completed the GHQ-12 and the Spanish version of the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS; Garcia-Esteve, Ascaso, Ojuel, & Navarro, 2003). The data used for this study were collected in the second phase. Participants were stratified and randomly selected within each stratum for clinical evaluation based on their EPDS outcomes. This resulted in a sample of 363 women who were clinically diagnosed and had no missing data on the GHQ-12 items. Of these, 170 had a psychiatric diagnosis and 193 were diagnosed as no cases.

The mean age of the final sample was 31.3 years (SD = 5.33; range = 16-44). Fifty-seven women (15.7%) were foreigners, mostly from South American countries (13.7%). This was the first child for 234 (64.5%) women, while 129 (35.5%) were multiparous. Occupational status was as follows: 296 (81.5%) worked outside the home, while 67 (18.5%) indicated home duties. One hundred women (27.5%) reported that they had university education, while just 23 (6.3%) said they had no formal education.

sec.title: Sociodemographic questionnaire
sec.p: This questionnaire collected information about the following variables: age, education level, marital status, number of children, and employment status during pregnancy.

sec.title: The Twelve-Item Spanish version of the General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12)
sec.p: The GHQ-12 (Lobo & Muñoz, 1996) contains 12 items (six positively worded items and six negatively worded items) that evaluate psychiatric morbidity using a four-level alternative response scale. There are three methods for scoring the GHQ-12—binary, corrected, and Likert—with higher scores indicating higher levels of psychological strain.

sec.title: The Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (EPDS)
sec.p: The EPDS (Cox, Holden, & Sagovsky, 1987) is a 10-item measure developed to assist primary care health professionals to detect whether mothers are suffering from postnatal depression (specifically it detects symptoms during the last week). It is typically self-administered, requiring about 5 minutes to complete. Scales of each item range from 0 to 3, so total scores can range from 0 to 30. The EPDS is used internationally and has been translated into various languages and tested worldwide. Garcia-Esteve et al. (2003) confirmed the validity of the Spanish version of the EPDS to identify postnatal depression.

sec.title: The Structured Clinical Interview for DSM-IV Axis I Disorders (nonpatient version, SCID-I/NP)
sec.p: The SCID-I/NP (First, Spitzer, Gibbon, & Williams, 1997) was used to establish psychiatric diagnoses. This interview consists of standardized diagnostic questions arranged in modules corresponding to each DSM-IV Axis I disorder (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders [4th ed.], American Psychiatric Association, 1994). DSM-IV diagnostic groups were the following: (a) mood disorders—major depression episode, minor depression episode, and dysthymia; (b) anxiety disorders—generalized anxiety disorder, panic disorder with or without agoraphobia, agoraphobia without history of panic disorder, social phobia, obsessive compulsive disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, and no specified anxiety disorder including women who meet all the generalized anxiety disorder criteria except for the 6-month duration criterion or subthreshold forms of fear about the health or breathing of the newborn or to leave the house without a companion; and (c) adjustment disorders—all cases precipitated by life events apart from delivery, such as illnesses, newborn hospital admission, partner relationship problems, partner violence, and economic or work difficulties.

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: CFA was used to compare the plausibility of several factor models. A common assumption has been that in working out an adequate sample size for factor analysis the ratio of subjects per variable is central. Kass and Tinsley (1979) recommended that between 5 and 10 subjects per variable is necessary (see also, Gorsuch, 1983). In this study, we were able to satisfy the recommended minimum of 5 participants-per-item ratio.

The models evaluated can be divided into three types: (a) the original unidimensional model and the unidimensional model with method effects (correlated error terms on the negative-phrased items; Hankins, 2008a), (b) two-factor models (Gureje & Obikoya, 1990; Politi et al., 1994; Schmitz et al., 1999), and (c) three-factor models (Daradkeh et al., 2001; Farrell, 1998; Graetz, 1991; A. J. Martin, 1999; Worsley & Gribbin, 1977).

The CFAs were conducted using MPlus Version 5.1 (Muthén & Muthén, 1998-2007). Excepting Hankins’s (2008a) unitary model, the other models were specified without correlation between the measurement errors and with correlations between factors. Each model was analyzed using mean and variance corrected weighted least squares (WLSMV), and the analysis was conducted on the polychoric or tetrachoric correlation matrix generated from the raw data. Correlation matrices were calculated using the two-stage procedure described by Olsson (1979).

It has been emphasized that it is desirable to use different indices to examine a model goodness of fit (Marsh, Balla, & Hau, 1996). The fit of the models was assessed by three measures that have been studied in the case of binary observed variables (Yu, 2002). The root mean square error of approximation measures the fit of the model to the covariance matrix. As a guideline, values <.06 indicate a close fit. The nonnormed fit index, also known as the Tucker–Lewis index, provides a measure of the incremental fit of the model. The minimum adequate value is .95. The comparative fit index is an incremental fit index based on the chi-square noncentrality parameter and has a range of 0 to 1, with 1 being a perfect fit and a target value ≥.96. To choose between the candidate models, we took into account the values of the fit indices, the correlation between the factors, and the principle of parsimony.

The current study also provided a good opportunity to test whether a multiple factor model of the GHQ-12 added any discriminant information for clinical purposes. As a clinical diagnosis was available in this sample (Phase 2), it was decided that a test of the discriminant ability of the Graetz (1991) model would be appropriate as this is the one that has received the most consistent support in the literature (Campbell et al., 2003; Cheung, 2002; French & Tait, 2004; Gao et al., 2004; Mäkikangas et al., 2006; C. R. Martin & Newell, 2005; Shevlin & Adamson, 2005). Therefore, in addition to CFA the discriminant efficiency of the Graetz (1991) model was evaluated, following on from the work of Gao et al. (2004), using discriminant function analysis. The formal diagnosis on the SCID-I/NP was used as the dependent variable and the factor scores derived from the model as the predictor variables. The symmetry of the distribution of the predictor variables was assessed and it was found that the distributions were almost symmetric and no important outlier values were present, making the choice of discriminant function analysis a reasonable one (Pohar, Blas, & Turk, 2004). Only those participants with diagnoses of depression, anxiety, or no diagnosis were included in the analysis.

sec.title: Confirmatory Factor Analyses
sec.p: Table 1 shows goodness-of-fit statistics for the models estimated. All the models do equally well when the data were scored in the original or the corrected format. All the models scored above the criterion for “good” fit in almost all the indices. The results for the Likert scoring showed less homogeneity but the differences were still minimal. None of the models had a root mean square error of approximation value below the recommended .06 cutoff, and some of the models had a comparative fit index below .96.

caption.p: Fit Indices for Alternative Factor Models of the GHQ-12

fn.p: Note. GHQ-12 = 12-Item General Health Questionnaire; RMSEA = root mean square error of approximation; CFI = comparative fit index; NNFI = nonnormed fit index.

sec.p: Comparing the various two- and three-factor models with the unitary case, it can be observed that no particular model is better than a single-factor model, especially in the case of the original and corrected scoring. With the Likert scoring there are some models that fit the data marginally better than the unitary one but the differences are small.

Table 2 shows the factor loadings and factor correlations for the various models evaluated using the Likert scoring. The factor loadings ranged between .51 and .94 (with the exception of the ones that load on two factors). The factors were highly correlated, with correlations from .75 to 1. This was also observed when using the corrected and the original scoring with correlations ranging between .91 and 1. These strong correlations suggest that even if there were in fact more than one factor, in practice it may be very difficult to discern them.

caption.p: Standardized Item Loadings for Factors and Correlations Between Factors (Likert Scoring)

sec.p: Concerning the unidimensional models, it can be observed that using the Likert scoring, the Hankins (2008a) model fits the data slightly better according to the goodness-of-fit measures. In addition, as we expected the variances of the item responses were higher for the negative-worded items (Figure 1), which is an indication of the “method effect” that is known to create “spurious” dimensions (Hankins, 2008b). In the case of the binary and corrected scoring, we did not find differences between the unidimensional models.

caption.p: Variances and 95% confidence intervals for the 12-item General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12) items (Likert scoring)

sec.title: Discriminant Function Analysis
sec.p: From the SCID-I/NP, 193 of the participants (53.2%) were given no diagnosis, 99 (27.3%) were identified as having a depressive disorder, 22 (6.1%) were classified as suffering an anxiety disorder, and 48 were classified as having a mixed disorder (13.4%). Only the first three groups were used as the groups in the dependent variable for the discriminant analysis. The calculated scores on the Graetz (1991) factors were used as the predictors.

A significant discrimination was found (Wilks’s Λ = .459, F[6, 618] = 49.006, p < .001), though the overall efficiency was clearly poor (values of Λ close to 0 indicate best discrimination). The first factor (from Graetz, 1991) had the best discrimination (partial Λ = .84), with the second and third factors providing nearly equal levels of discrimination (partial Λ = .96 and .97, respectively). Only one of the derived roots was significant (root 1: canonical R = .73, χ2(6) = 241.3, p < .001; root 2: canonical R = .13, χ2(2) = 5.03, p < .1). The overall discrimination is best illustrated in Figure 2, which plots the scores derived from the roots for each participant identified by group. The groups sort into two main “clouds” with no clear discrimination between them. The variation is obviously on Root 1 with little or no variation evident on Root 2.

caption.p: Scatterplot of canonical scores using Graetz’s (1991) factors

sec.p: From inspection of Figure 2 it was also clear that the discriminant function was only able to discriminate between participants with no diagnosis and those with a diagnosis. There was no discrimination between those with depressive disorders and those with anxiety disorders. This was confirmed from the classification of cases using the canonical roots. A total of 92% of the cases in the no-diagnosis group and 80% of the cases in the depressive-disorder group were correctly classified. But none of the cases in the anxiety-disorder group was correctly classified.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: To our knowledge, this is the first study that has examined the fit of alternative factor models of the GHQ-12 in postpartum women, using the three alternative scoring methods of the instrument as well as estimation methods specially recommended for categorical and binary data while taking into account method effects. The CFAs suggested that the unitary model with method effects proposed by Hankins (2008a, 2008b) was the best-fitting and parsimonious model when the Likert scoring method was used. However, we found that the unitary model without method effects was the best-fitting model for the other scoring methods. This difference might be because of the different estimation methods used (maximum likelihood vs. WLSMV). Overall, our results uphold Hankins’s (2008a, 2008b) findings, demonstrating that the multidimensional factor structures obtained in previous studies were an artifact of response styles associated with the phrasing of the items. In fact, a typical outcome in the factor analysis of psychological instruments comprising a mixture of positively and negatively phrased items is to obtain two factors that are most likely artifactual whereby positively phrased items load on one factor and negatively phrased items on another (Spector, Van Katwyk, Brannick, & Chen, 1997; Woods, 2006).

Wang and Cunningham (2005) compared different estimation methods in CFA of the GHQ-12 and concluded that the best fit is obtained when estimating models based on nonnormal ordinal responses using polychoric correlations with diagonally weighted least squares (Jöreskog, 1990), which is similar to the WLSMV estimator that we used and elicits almost identical results (Dolan, 1994). Therefore, one of the main strengths of our study was that we took into account that the variables were ordinal or binary using an appropriate estimator and fit indices.

Most studies that stated that the GHQ-12 is multidimensional reported high correlations between the factors (Campbell & Knowles, 2007; French & Tait, 2004; Gao et al., 2004; C. R. Martin & Newell, 2005). In general, the studies that focused on the dimensionality of the GHQ-12 and used CFA reported high correlations between the factors but not as high as the ones we have obtained. It is important to note that when using maximum likelihood estimation with ordinal variables the model parameters are underestimated (Babakus et al., 1987; Muthén & Kaplan, 1992) and this could be one of the reasons why these studies have obtained smaller factor correlations.

The high correlation between factors made some of the authors consider that it was most convenient and practical to work with the GHQ-12 as a unitary measure (Campbell & Knowles, 2007; French & Tait, 2004; Gao et al., 2004). Gao et al. (2004) selected the Graetz (1991) model as the best-fitting one but then examined the three-factor scores and the overall GHQ-12 score in relation to clinical diagnoses and concluded that “from a pragmatic point of view we consider it acceptable to use this instrument as a one-dimensional measure” (p. 6). Similarly, Campbell and Knowles (2007) reported the factor correlations and interpreted them to conclude that “any factorial structure is likely to be of only marginal use over the single summary score” (p. 7). Despite the strong evidence for a unitary factor model of the GHQ-12, it would seem useful for future studies to explore the structural invariance of the unitary factor loadings using cross-gender and/or cross-cultural comparison samples.

Further supporting the argument made by Gao et al. (2004) and Campbell and Knowles (2007), the Graetz scores provided little effective discrimination between diagnostic groups. Only the first Graetz factor had any real discriminant power with the other two appearing to be quite ineffective. The overall discriminant function only discriminated between diagnosed and nondiagnosed cases and provided no finer discrimination. This is obviously no more efficient than the usual discrimination derived from the cutoff points of the total GHQ score.

To sum up, the GHQ-12 seems to be best understood as a unitary measure of psychiatric morbidity. The current study explored the issue of whether different approaches for scoring the GHQ-12 combined with the inappropriate statistical methods used plus the influence of possible method effects explain some of the inconsistencies in previous research. It was found that when appropriate estimation approaches were used and when method effects were taken into account there was no evidence to support a multidimensional interpretation of the GHQ-12. This was further evaluated using a discriminant function analysis that demonstrated that there was no advantage to using a multidimensional approach to scoring. In practice, the GHQ-12 should be scored as a unidimensional measure regardless of the specific scoring system used. It seems, therefore, that GHQ-12 should continue to be used as a general screening tool and should not be pressed into service as a measure of outcome across different clinical dimensions.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interests with respect to the authorship and/or publication of this article.
